Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Remote Sensing of Urban Tree Species and Tree Stress

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will develop a robust methodology to map the species and stress symptom level of individual broadleaf deciduous trees in North American cities. The project will provide new insights regarding ways to integrate information about spectral-temporal variability from remotely sensed images with field inventories of tree species and stress symptom levels. By furthering the potential to reduce labor-intensive fieldwork and instead use new, high-resolution remote sensing imagery to assess tree species and stress symptom levels, this project can help advance research on the interplay of different factors on the health of urban forests. The project will help advance the practice of urban forest management, which has significant societal value because healthy urban forests improve urban air quality, enhance ground water maintenance, and moderate urban air temperatures. Although this project will focus on a case study in Washington, D.C., the development of an accurate, robust, and repeatable methodology for using widely available, state-of-the-art remote sensing data to update forest inventories of tree species and tree stress will have utility in a much broader set of urban and rural settings. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

More than half of the world's population now lives in cities, and the biodiversity and health of trees has been widely recognized as central to the sustainability of urban environments. The doctoral student conducting this project will develop a robust and accurate method to identify tree species and stress symptom level to improve urban sustainability using optimized suite of remote sensing data and machine-learning algorithms. She will seek answers to two questions related to phenological variations in the foliage of different kinds of trees at different times of the year: (1) With the leaf pigment-induced changes in the visible-light spectral bands, will spring leaf emergence and fall senescence phenology periods be most informative to predict tree species? (2) Will the magnitude of decline in near infrared reflectance spectral bands during late summer be the most predictive component to predict changes in stress symptom level within a certain tree species? This project will pair large field inventories from the District of Columbia Department of Transportation with a suite of WorldView-3 satellite images to map the tree species and stress symptom levels of more than 7,000 trees along Washington streets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To maintain a sustainable urban environment, deriving tree species and tree health information are essential tasks for urban foresters. The rapid development of very high-resolution remote sensing images provides the opportunities to obtain such information instead of traditional field surveys in species-rich urban settings. With the support of NSF funding, we purchased 12 sets of WorldView-3 high spatial resolution images to 1) detect different tree stress levels at individual tree level; 2) discriminate tree species using machine learning algorithms at two taxonomic levels in Washington D.C.

First, we measured six vegetation indices from three images taken in 2017, and found NDVI has the highest potential to describe the statistical differences between three trees stress levels identified in the field (good, fair and poor). Thus, we reported that high spatial resolution remote sensing images can provide a timely tree health assessment based on spectral differences at individual tree crown levels. We also found that the greendown phenology is an essential factor to be considered when using vegetation indices from different years or months for tree health assessment.

Second, we leveraged these 12 very high-resolution WorldView-3 images, whose acquisition date covers each pheno-phase of the growing season from April to November, with the ground truth tree inventory data including nearly 50,000 trees from Washington D.C. Department of Transportation’s (DDOT). We reported a successful classification of top 19 tree species with an overall accuracy of 63.7%, and a promising classification of the ten most abundant genera with an overall accuracy of 75.6%. We also discussed the effects of pheno-phases on the classification at different taxonomic levels. We concluded that our classification is largely hampered by the spectral similarity between species in the same genus.

Funding from this project enhanced our collaboration with DDOT. Our results contributed to the tree inventory update and maintenance process in Washington D.C. Based on our findings, we proposed strategies for using high-resolution satellite data in urban settings, especially for tree health assessment. Our project provided the insight that very high-resolution satellite images are powerful tools in species-rich urban settings for both tree species and tree health management. Professionals from DDOT also proposed future research and collaborations with us about tree stress analysis. Though our project was conducted in Washington, D.C., the development of this repeatable methodology and routine can be used widely in other cities to better understand street trees and make more timely management decisions.

Funding from this project resulted in two dissertation chapters for the co-PI’s research, which are already available online.  The co-PI has successfully graduated with a Ph.D. degree in geography from West Virginia University in 2019. In addition, these two manuscripts are also currently under review in two peer-reviewed journals, one is in remote sensing and the other one is in urban forestry discipline. Under the support of this funding, the co-PI also presented these outcomes at both academic and non-academic conferences, including American Association of Geographers in April 2018 and 2019, International Society of Arboriculture in August 2018, American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting in December 2018, and ESRI Annual User’s conference in July 2019.
